description: The queen of mathematics: properties of integers.

slides.title: What is Number Theory?
slides.content:
# Integers only üî¢

Study of properties of positive integers ($1, 2, 3...$).
- **Primes**, factors, divisibility.
- Formerly "Pure Math", now essential for **Cryptography**.

slides.title: Prime Numbers
slides.content:
# The Atoms of Math ‚öõÔ∏è

Numbers with exactly two factors: 1 and itself.
2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17...
- 2 is the *only* even prime.
- **Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic**: Every integer is a unique product of primes ($12 = 2 \times 2 \times 3$).

slides.title: Divisibility Rules
slides.content:
# Shortcuts ‚úÇÔ∏è

- Div by 2: Even (ends 0,2,4,6,8).
- Div by 3: Sum of digits div by 3 ($123 \to 1+2+3=6$).
- Div by 5: Ends in 0 or 5.
- Div by 9: Sum of digits div by 9.

slides.title: GCD and LCM
slides.content:
# Common Ground ü§ù

- **GCD (Greatest Common Divisor)**: Biggest number that divides both.
- **LCM (Least Common Multiple)**: Smallest number both divide into.
Using Euclid's Algorithm to find GCD efficiently.

slides.title: Prime Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which of these is a Prime Number?

slides.title: Modular Arithmetic
slides.content:
# Clock Math üï∞Ô∏è

Dealing with remainders.
$A \pmod N$

$14 \equiv 2 \pmod{12}$ (14 o'clock is 2 o'clock).
Used heavily in coding and encryption.

slides.title: Fermat's Little Theorem
slides.content:
# Prime Power ‚ö°

If $p$ is prime:
$$a^p \equiv a \pmod p$$

Essential for testing primality of huge numbers.

slides.title: RSA Encryption
slides.content:
# Secret Codes üîê

Modern internet security relies on the fact that:
- Multiplying primes is easy ($p \times q = N$).
- Factoring $N$ back into $p$ and $q$ is incredibly hard if numbers are huge.

slides.title: Diophantine Equations
slides.content:
# Integer Solutions üß©

Equations where only integer solutions are allowed.
$3x + 4y = 7$
- No fractions allowable.
- Fermat's Last Theorem ($x^n + y^n = z^n$ has no solution for $n > 2$).

slides.title: Perfect Numbers
slides.content:
# Sum of Parts üåü

Number equal to sum of its proper divisors.
- $6$ ($1+2+3$).
- $28$ ($1+2+4+7+14$).
- We don't know if any odd perfect numbers exist.

slides.title: Euclidean Algorithm
slides.content:
# Ancient Algo üìú

Finding GCD of A and B.
1. Divide A by B, get remainder R.
2. Divide B by R.
3. Repeat until remainder is 0. Last divisor is GCD.
Still the fastest way.

slides.title: Sieve of Eratosthenes
slides.content:
# Finding Primes üï∏Ô∏è

Algorithm to find all primes up to N.
1. List 2 to N.
2. Circle 2, cross out all multiples of 2.
3. Circle next available (3), cross out multiples.
4. Repeat.

slides.title: Twin Primes
slides.content:
# Best Friends üëØ

Primes with gap of 2.
- (3, 5)
- (11, 13)
- (41, 43)
Conjecture: There are infinitely many twin primes.

slides.title: Goldbach Conjecture
slides.content:
# Unsolved ‚ùì

"Every even integer greater than 2 is the sum of two primes."
$10 = 3 + 7$
$100 = 3 + 97$
Seems true, but never proven!

slides.title: Fibonacci Sequence
slides.content:
# Nature's Code üåª

0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13...
Each number is sum of previous two.
- Connected to **Golden Ratio** ($\phi$).
- Appears in sunflowers, pinecones, shells.

slides.title: Congruences
slides.content:
# Matching Relations ‚öñÔ∏è

$a \equiv b \pmod m$
Means m divides $a - b$.
Allows arithmetic on remainders: $(A + B) \pmod m = (A \pmod m + B \pmod m) \pmod m$.

slides.title: Infinity of Primes
slides.content:
# Never Ending üõ§Ô∏è

Euclid proved there is no largest prime.
- Assume finite list. Multiply all + 1.
- New number is not divisible by any on list.
- Therefore list is incomplete.

slides.title: Number Theory Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Primes** build all numbers.
- **Modular Arithmetic** is the math of cycles.
- It underpins **Internet Security**.
- Full of simple questions with impossibly hard answers.
